text.p: Here are highlights of stories reported by Hungary's press, based on information by Nepszabadsag's Hungary Around the Clock service. For further details on how to subscribe to Hungary Around the Clock, please contact Monica Kovacs at (361) 351 7142 or fax your request to (361) 351 7141.
ALL PAPERS
- President Arpad Goncz proceeded to Asuncion, capital of Paraguay, yesterday after winding up talks in Argentina.
- Luxembourg Foreign Minister and Deputy Premier Jacques Poos stressed in Budapest on Wednesday that Hungary, of the countries seeking to join the EU, stands the best chance of gaining admission.

- NATO Deputy Secretary General Norman W. Ray pointed out to Defence Minister Gyorgy Keleti in Budapest that there is no centrally guided arms procurement within NATO, nor does the alliance set any binding requirements for arms purchases and modernisation.

- Minister of Justice Pal Vastagh said on Wednesday that the coalition is to use its 72 percent majority to pass a constitutional amendment required for a reform of the justice system, if no consensus is reached with the opposition.

- Gyula Kosa, president of the Agricultural Producers' Advocacy Organisation (Metesz) announced that Metesz will take the government. Nepszabadsag prints the full text of the MTI correspondent's report taken from a tape recording of Kosa's speech at a meeting last Saturday.
- Hungary exported $2.381 billion in January-February, while imports totalled $2.812 billion, said Deputy State Secretary at the Ministry of Industry Lajos Berenyi.
- Industrial production prices in February increased 2.1 percent on January and 22.5 percent on a year earlier.
- GDP could grow by up to 2 percent this year along with an inflation rate of 18-19 percent, according to managing director of market research institute Kopint-Datorg.
- National Police Commander Laszlo Forgacs said that crime rose 6.2 percent in the first three months of the year, particulary white collar crime and that related to property and drug abuse.
NEPSZAVA
- This paper reports that the State Audit Office and the Government Supervisory Office are examining the circumstances of the disputed missile systems tender launched by the Defence Ministry.
MAGYAR HIRLAP
- The Smallholders Party has convened a national agricultural round table conference for the weekend. People's Party MP Gyorgy Rasko dismissed the plan as an election ploy.
- Representatives of 30 political parties from the region are expected to attend a three-day conference at Lakitelek on April 18-20 hosted by the Democratic Forum.
VILAGGAZDASAG
- The cabinet today is expected to hear a report on the main guidelines of economic policy between 1990 and 2000.
- EBRD financed seven projects to a total value of ECU 133 million in Hungary last year, the bank's annual report reveals.
- Merrill Lynch analyst Tom Chadwick said Hungary is in a very strong position as it may be in a period of sustainable economic growth.
- EBRD board of directors has approved a $30 million subordinated loan to K&H Bank.
NEPSZABADSAG
- Interior Minister Gabor Kuncze and Avigdor Kahalani, the Israeli Minister of Internal Security signed a pact according to which crime-fighting bodies will coordinate work.

- Police have recently recommended that the Capital's prosecutor's office should ask Parliament to suspend the immunity rights of Socialist MP Zoltan Haller of Esztergom, on suspicion of misuse of funds, embezzlement and bribery.
